solution:
In general,
\[\frac{1}{2} \begin{vmatrix} x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1 \end{vmatrix}\]is the signed area of the triangle with vertices at $(x_1,y_1),$ $(x_2,y_2),$ and $(x_3,y_3).$  (The area is signed, i.e. it can be positive or negative, depending on the orientation of the triangle.)  Here, the sides of the triangle are 3, 4, and 5, which is a right triangle.  Therefore, its area is $\frac{1}{2} \cdot 3 \cdot 4 = 6.$  Then
\[\begin{vmatrix} x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1 \end{vmatrix} = \pm 12,\]so
\[\begin{vmatrix} x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1 \end{vmatrix}^2 = \boxed{144}.\]
model_solution:
Step 1:  We are given real numbers $x_1,$ $x_2,$ $x_3,$ $y_1,$ $y_2,$ and $y_3$ that satisfy three equations involving squares of differences between these numbers.
Step 2:  The first step involves expanding the determinant of a $3 \times 3$ matrix, which can be expressed as a sum of products of elements along its diagonals.
Step 3:  To start evaluating this determinant, we expand it along the first row. This expansion leads to terms involving the individual elements of the matrix.
Step 4:  By expanding the determinant along the first row, we express it in terms of $2 \times 2$ determinants, which can be further simplified using the formula for the determinant of a $2 \times 2$ matrix.
Step 5:  This process allows us to express the determinant in terms of the given real numbers $x_1,$ $x_2,$ $x_3,$ $y_1,$ $y_2,$ and $y_3$.

The given equations are:
\begin{align*}

\begin{align*}
&\begin{vmatrix} x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1 \end{vmatrix}^2\\
=\ & \left( \begin{vmatrix} x_1 & y_1 \\ x_2 & y_2 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} x_2 & y_2 \\ x_3 & y_3 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} x_3 & y_3 \\ x_1 & y_1 \end{vmatrix} \right)^2\\
=\ & \left( x_1 y_2 - x_2 y_1 + x_2 y_3 - x_3 y_2 + x_3 y_1 - x_1 y_3 \right)^2\\
=\ & (x_1 y_2 - x_2 y_1 + x_2 y_3 - x_3 y_2 + x_3 y_1 - x_1 y_3)^2\\
=\
We have
\begin{align*}
(x_1 - x_2)^2 + (y_1 - y_2)^2 &= 9, \\
(x_1 - x_3)^2 + (y_1 - y_3)^2 &= 16, \\
(x_2 - x_3)^2 + (y_2 - y_3)^2 &= 25.
\end{align*}
We will square the determinant of the $3 \times 3$ matrix to simplify the given expression.

$$\begin{vmatrix} x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1 \end{vmatrix}^2 = (x_1 y_2 - x_2 y_1 + x_2 y_3 - x_3 y_2 + x_3 y_1 - x_1 y_3)^2$$
$$\begin{vmatrix} x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1 \end{vmatrix}^2 = (x_1 y_2 - x_2 y_1 + x_2 y_3 - x_3 y_2 + x_3 y_1 - x_1 y_3)^2$$
$$= (x_1 y_2 + x_2 y_3 - x_2 y_1 - x_3 y_2 + x_3 y_1 - x_1 y_3)^2$$
$$=\ (x_1 y_2 + x_2 y_3 - x_2 y_1 - x_3 y_2 + x_3 y_1 - x_1 y_3)^2$$
$$=\ (x_1y_2-x_2y_1+x_2y_3-x_3y_2+x_3y_1-x_1y_3)^2$$
$$=\ (x_1y_2-x_2y_1+x_2y_3-x_3y_2+x_3y_1-x_1y_3)^2$$
$$\begin{vmatrix} x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1 \end{vmatrix}^2 = (x_1 y_2 - x_2 y_1 + x_2 y_3 - x_3 y_2 + x_3 y_1 - x_1 y_3)^2 = (x_1 y_2 + x_2 y_3 - x_2 y_1 - x_3 y_2 + x_3 y_1 - x_1 y_3)^2 = (x_1y_2-x_2y_1+x_2y_3-x_3y_2+x_3y_1-x_1y_3)^2$$

$$=\ (x_1y_2-x_2y_1+x_2y_3-x_3y_2+x_3y_1-x_1y_3)^2$$

$$=\ (x_1y_2-x_2y_1+x_2y_3-x_3y_2+x
Expand the square:
$$(x_1 y_2 - x_2 y_1 + x_2 y_3 - x_3 y_2 + x_3 y_1 - x_1 y_3)^2$$
$$= (x_1 y_2 + x_2 y_3 - x_2 y_1 - x_3 y_2 + x_3 y_1 - x_1 y_3)^2$$
$$= (x_1y_2-x_2y_1+x_2y_3-x_3y_2+x_3y_1-x_1y_3)^2$$
$$(x_1y_2-x_2y_1+x_2y_3-x_3y_2+x_3y_1-x_1y_3)^2$$
$$=\ (x_1y_2-x_2y_1+x_2y_3-x_3y_2+x_3y_1-x_1y_3)^2$$
Since the determinant is equal to the square of the given expression, we can directly square the given expression. We have
$$(x_1 y_2 - x_2 y_1 + x_2 y_3 - x_3 y_2 + x_3 y_1 - x_1 y_3)^2$$

We can then simplify the expression by expanding the square:
$$(x_1 y_2 - x_2 y_1 + x_2 y_3 - x_3 y_2 + x_3 y_1 - x_1 y_3)^2$$
$$= (x_1 y_2 + x_2 y_3 - x_2 y_1 - x_3 y_2 + x_3 y_1 - x_1 y_3)^2$$
$$= (x_1y_2-x_2y_1+x_2y_3-x_3y_2+x_3y_1-x_1y_3)^2$$
